title: Approaches to Christian Studies
description: An introduction to different theological reflections of the interpretation of Christian belief and practices, and their correlation to other disciplines and everyday life.
outcome: 1. Students are equipped to have the knowledge and critical ability to make a theological reflection of Christian belief and practice; 2. Students are trained to have the intellectual ability and consciousness to correlate theology to other disciplines, such as, science, politics and philosophy; 3. Students are educated to have the knowledge and imagination to construct their own theologies in the context of their everyday life.

title: Introduction to the Hebrew Bible
description: This course is a survey of the books which made up the Hebrew Scriptures, and the lives of the people whom these books are about. It covers the period of the Patriarchs to the beginning of the Christian era within the context of the ancient Near Eastern world. This historical survey will also introduce students to the life and faith and literature of the Hebrew people. During the course, students are expected to read and become familiar with the Hebrew Scripture.
outcome: 1. The students will know and understand a. the general overview of the contents in the Hebrew Bible; b. the direct relationship of the composition of the books to her contexts; c. a general grasp of the scholarship pertaining to the study of the Hebrew Bible; d. the meaning of the Hebrew Bible as Christian Canon/Scripture.  2. The students can describe, explain and discuss a. the main issues related to the critical study of the books in the Hebrew Bible; b. the main issues of critical scholarship concerning the composition and redaction of the books, as well as the origin and identity of Israel; c. the proposed historical contexts of the Hebrew Bible; d. the relationships or/and tensions between the traditions underlying the theological motivations and the contemporary situation/s of the text.  3. The students will appreciate a. the making/compilation of the Hebrew Bible; b. the necessity for language acquisition in the study of the Hebrew Bible; c. the diverse research faculties in the study of the Hebrew Bible.
syllabus: Topics  (Key concepts)  Introduction (Imaginative Remembering; Genre) Torah, Genesis;  (Myth, Legend and ANET) Exodus, Leviticus; (Cult and Priestly school) Numbers, Deuteronomy; (Law and Narrative) Prophets, Joshua, Judges; (History and Deuteronomistic History) 1 and 2 Samuel, 1 and 2 Kings;  (Prophet in Narrative) Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel; (Literary Prophet and Their Social World) Minor Prophets; (Twelve prophet as a book) Writings, Psalms; (Poetry as Torah) Job; Proverbs (Wisdom Literature) Five Scrolls; (Hebrew Bible and the early Judaism) Daniel, Ezra, Nehemiah,  (2nd Temple Literature) 1 and 2 Chronicles;  (The Rewritten Bible)

title: Introduction to the New Testament
description: This course is a survey of the New Testament Church, its life, faith and literature within the context of the Mediterranean world. During the course, students are expected to read and become familiar with the contents of the New Testament.
outcome: A) Knowledge Outcome:  - To give students a general understanding of the text of the New Testament, its methods of studies, its background and the issues involved.   B) Attitude Outcomes: - To develop students’ appreciation of the New Testament text as well as the diversity of interpretation of it. - To develop students’ ability to have a critical, yet sympathetic understanding of the New Testament. - To develop students’ analytical mind in reading scholarly opinions.

title: Pentateuchal Studies
description: Exegesis of selected passages from Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers and Deuteronomy.

title: Prophetic Literature
description: Exegesis of selected passages from Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel and the Twelve Prophets.

title: Wisdom and the Psalms
description: Exegesis of selected passages from Job, Proverb, Ecclesiates, Psalms and also from Wisdom passages from the prophets.

title: Synoptic Gospels
description: This course comprises a study of the synoptic problem, the characteristics, purpose and theology of the three Synoptic Gospels, and a detailed exegesis of selected passages from the Gospels both of Matthew and of Luke, including comparison with parallel passages in the Gospel according to Mark.

title: Johannine Literature
description: Study of selected passages from the Gospel according to John, the Epistles of John and Revelation (Apocalypse), including questions of authorship, purpose and main emphasis.

title: Pauline Letters
description: Study of selected passages from Romans, 1 and 2 Corinthians, Galatians, 1 and 2 Thessalonians, Ephesians, Philippians and Colossians, including general questions of date, authorship, setting, purpose and main theological emphasis.
outcome: Knowledge Outcomes: - To have the overview on the interpretation history of Pauline letters and their emphasis, development and trend. - To have an overview on the key concepts and theological motifs of Pauline letters.  Skill Outcome: - To be equipped with the necessary interpretation skills, based on the socio-rhetorical interpretation, to develop their own interpretation on Pauline letters.
syllabus: I) List of Topics  1. Problem in interpreting Pauline Letters Learning the complication of interpreting Paul from historical and theological perspectives.  2. Basic concepts in interpreting Pauline Letters Introducing various basic concepts in interpreting Paul including who Paul was, the context of Paul and the language Paul used, etc.  3. Interpretation History of Pauline Letters Learning the development and differences in concerns and assumptions of various main stream interpretations beginning from the reformation.  4. Pauline Theological motifs Learning the key theological motifs scholars generated from the undisputed Pauline letters.  5. Socio-rhetorical interpretation (SI) Learning the methodology of SI and how it could help us to bring the economic “texture” into biblical exegesis.  6. Detail analysis of selected passages from Romans, Philemon and Philippians Selected passages will be analyzed using the method and concepts introduced in the course   II) Course Schedule  Session 1:  Course Introduction + Problems in interpreting Paul  Session 2:  Basic concept in interpreting Pauline letters  Session 3: Interpretation history of Pauline letters  Session 4:  Context of Paul (1): 2nd temple Judaism and New Perspective of Paul  Session 5: Context of Paul (2): Social World of Paul including the Political and Economic situation of Roman Empire  Session 6: Core Pauline theological motif 1 - Theology  Session 7: Core Pauline theological motif 2 – Eschatology  Session 8: Core Pauline theological motif 3 - Christology  Session 9: Core Pauline theological motif 4 - Love  Session 10: Interpretation Method: Socio-rhetorical Interpretation 2  Session 11: Letter to Philemon: Demonstration of SRI application  Session 12: Conclusion

title: Early and Medieval Church
description: The purpose of the course is to introduce the students to the historical and theological developments in the early and medieval church, from Jesus to the 15th century. The course offers a general knowledge of the theological and ecclesial development during the covered period and helps students get acquainted with different perspectives on church history and with issues that are still debated.
outcome: The students will gain a general knowledge of the theological and ecclesial development during the covered period and get acquainted with different perspectives on church history and with issues that are still debated. The students will also develop sensitivity regarding the diversity of Christian faith expressions.
syllabus: Session 1 - The church in the first two centuries Session 2 - Christianity and politics: Conflicts with the State; the extension of Christianity in the first three centuries Session 3 - Challenges to the Faith in the Second Century and the Development of Early Catholic Theology Session 4 - Christianity and culture: The encounter with Hellenist philosophy and the development of Patristic theology Session 5 - Christianity becoming the religion of the empire: Constantine and his impact on the religious life of the Catholic Church Session 6 - Theological and ecclesial controversies of the 4th Century: Donatism and Arianism Session 7 - Theology and christological debates in the 5th century: The Council of Chalcedon; Augustine Session 8 - Mission history in medieval times: the extension of Christianity and its inculturation in new contexts Session 9 - Church and state: The growth of papal and ecclesial power through the middle ages and the conflict between emperor and  Session 10 - The history of a growing division: The churches in East and West on separate ways  Session 11 - The history of the other church: Revivalism, reform, and alternative Christian faith expression in the medieval time  Session 12 - Outward militancy and inward divisions in the high and late medieval time: the crusades, the inquisition and ecclesial divisions Session 13 - A short introduction to medieval theology

title: The Reformation Era
description: The development of Christian thought and institutions in the age of the Reformation.
outcome: a) The students will gain a general knowledge of the ecclesial and theological developments during the covered period.b) The students will learn how the shifts in 16th century Europe affected later historical and theological developments.c) Students will develop sensitivity regarding the diversity of Christian faith expressions.
syllabus: The purpose of the course is to introduce the students to the developments in church and theology in 16th century Europe, a crucial period in the history of the church, as it brought unprecedented changes that can be described as a paradigm shift in Christianity. After the course the student shall be able to understand different aspects of the transformations happening during this period: theological, spiritual, historical, social, cultural, political, and others. A special emphasis will be on the shifts in theological thinking and how these shifts affected the traditional configuration of society, state, culture, and religion.

title: Modern Western Christianity
description: The development of Christian thought and institutions in the post-Reformation and modern periods.

title: Humanity and Salvation
description: The Christian doctrine of humanity; the doctrine of sin and its consequences; various concepts of salvation; the doctrines of reconciliation, justification, sanctification, etc.; Christ and salvation.

title: God, Creation and Eschatoloty
description: A study of various ways of understanding of God, both traditional and contemporary; the doctrines of creation in their biblical, patristic and modern perspectives; and the doctrines of Eschatology. All with special emphasis on contemporary issues.

title: Christ, Church and Spirit
description: A survey of the formation of christological doctrines in the ancient church and modern interpretations; basic ideas of the church and the sacraments; and the Holy Spirit and the Christian life.

title: Catholic Dogmatics
description: In this course, we attempt to understand, in the light of developments up to and including the Second Vatican Council, what and how the Catholic Church conceives herself to be, and in such a conception, how she looks at the Bible, tradition and her sacramental life.

title: Systematic Theology I
description: This course is an introduction to the nature and methodologies of Christian theology, with particular attention to the historical creeds of the Christian Churches.
outcome: After completing this course, the student is expected (a) to have a basic understanding of the history of Christian theology; (b) to understand the nature and roles of various factors that influences the formation of theology (especially the Bible, but also tradition, culture, theological language, etc.); (c) to have elementary knowledge of exemplary theological systems and methods; (d) to develop a basic competence in appreciating theological texts.
syllabus: Session 1: What Is Systematic Theology?   Session 2: Emergence of Christian Theology in the Patristic Era   Session 3: Medieval and Reformation Theology   Session 4: Theology in Modernity   Session 5: Theological Language   Sessions 6-7: Scripture  Session 8:  Tradition  Session 9: Experience and Reason  Session 10: Culture and Society   Sessions 11-12: Theological Systems and Methods

title: Systematic Theology II
description: This course will be a survey of the Christian doctrines of God, Jesus Christ, human nature, the Holy Spirit, the Church and the last things. Attention will also be given to the contemporary development of theology.
outcome: After completing this course, the student is expected (a) to have some basic understanding of major Christian doctrines; (b) to be acquainted with important theological texts writings, especially those in the patristic era, the Reformation era, and the twentieth century; (c) to recognize the relevance of systematic theology for Christian life and churches.
syllabus: Session 1: Introduction / God  Sessions 2-3: Creation, Providence, and Evil  Sessions 4-5: The Person and Work of Christ  Session 6: Humanity, Sin, and Grace  Session 7: Christian Life and the Holy Spirit  Session 8: Holy Spirit and the Trinity  Session 9: Christian Hope and the Kingdom of God  Session 10: Church (I): Nature and Ministry  Session 11: Church (II): Sacraments  Session 12: Church (III): The Church in the World  Session 13: Theology of Religions

title: Pastoral Theology
description: This course covers three areas: (1) the place of Pastoral Theology in theological studies and its uniqueness; (2) different types of Pastoral Theology and their aims; and (3) church models and pastoral emphases.
outcome: 1. To understand what is Pastoral Theology with reflection from personal pastoral experience. 2. To construct Pastoral Theology from the Bible, church and Chinese cultural traditions. 3. To understand different emphases of Pastoral Theology from multiple perspectives and from histories of different denominations.
syllabus: 課程綱要  一）何謂牧養神學？  二）牧者為中心的牧養神學 *牧者的角色：牧人？羊？先知？祭司？領袖？僕人？教師？神學家？ *牧者的功能與責任：餵養？照顧？宣講？ 禮儀？領導？行政？教導？輔導？探訪？ 佈道？栽培？訓練？社會活動？社會服務？ *牧養範圍有何界線？  三）牧者與成長 *牧者的危機 *牧者成長的攔阻  四）信徒(需要)為中心的牧養神學 *信徒需要些什麼？ *對信徒有什麼期望？  五）信仰群體為中心的牧養神學 *教會存在的意義與功能 *教會的成長和發展  六）世界為中心的牧養神學 *在世與不屬世 *天國的使命  七）教會與發展 *聖禮、崇拜 *訓練與栽培 *教會增長與植堂  八）世界與個人 *社會、政治 *生寄死歸   課節安排  第一節：牧者的角色  第二節：何謂牧養神學  第三節：牧者的本質、功能與責任、牧者為中心的牧養神學  第四節：牧者的能力、恩賜、靈性、心態和心理健康  第五節：讀書報告分享  第六節：個人牧養、生寄死歸  第七節：聖經中教會的諸形象、教會為中心 的牧養神學  第八節：使命為中心的牧養神學  第九節：植堂策略個案研討  第十節：教會領導、組織文化在教會群體中的協同效應與信徒運動的推展  第十一節：崇拜、聖禮、聖曆與牧養  第十二節：教會增長研討  第十三節：多元化的牧養神學、牧養神學的再思

title: Foundation of Religious Education
description: This course is an introduction to religious education. Some of the central issues in religious education will be raised, including what kind of education it is, why is such education necessary, when and how is one to be educated, for what and to what extent, etc. Attempts will be made to relate religious education to other disciplines such as theology, education, psychology, sociology, philosophy.

title: Biblical Hebrew I
description: This course, and the sequel Biblical Hebrew II in the next semester, are designed to enable students to read Biblical Hebrew. In this course, Biblical Hebrew I, students learn the alphabets to the basic forms of Hebrew sentences. Students not only learn how to read simple sentences from the Hebrew bible, but also learn to identify different parts of speech, and basic grammar. Students will also learn some Hebrew songs which accompany the lessons. This course follows closely to its textbook, Learn Biblical Hebrew by John H. Dobson (2005). Biblical Hebrew I will cover Lessons 1-13.
outcome: Knowledge Outcomes (1) recite and write down from memory the Hebrew alphabets, vowels and their transliterations (2) pronounce and read Hebrew words (3) recite from memory Genesis 1:1 (D 2.4; p. 18); Deuteronomy 6:4-5 (D 5.6; p. 55); the songs: We welcome you (D 1.13 Q5; p. 16) and Blessed are You (D 5.9 Q6; p. 58) (4) memorize at least 350 Hebrew words perfectly by the end of the course (5) recognize words and identify them correctly as nouns, verbs, prepositions, constructs, suffixes, adjectives, infinitives or participles (6) identify the forms of questions, commands and requests (7) parse a given word (8) list the functions of adjectives, participles, infinitives, prefix and suffix conjugations, waw consecutive conjugation as well as concepts of perfective and non-perfective  Attitude Outcomes (1) develop an interest and respect for the historical and cultural development of the Hebrew language from its paleo-Hebrew script until its Aramaic script, and the modern Hebrew language (2) appreciate the distinctiveness of the Biblical Hebrew language  (3) cultivate an interest to read Biblical Hebrew texts
syllabus: 1. The Hebrew Alphabets and Vowels 2. Word Order in Sentences 3. The Pronominal Suffixes and Pronouns 4. The Narrative and Completed Action 5. Parsing 6. The Adjectives 7. Absolute and Construct Nouns 8. The Continuing Action 9. The Previous and Future Action 10. Possession and Question Tags 11. Commands and Requests 12. Infinitives 13. Numbers

title: Biblical Hebrew II
requirements: Prerequisite(s): THEO3217(1213) or THEO5301
description: This course, a sequel to Biblical Hebrew I, will continue to follow the textbook, Learn Biblical Hebrew by John H. Dobson (2005), covering Lessons 12–25. It will cover all the binyanim of Hebrew as well as understanding concepts of Hebrew syntax, function of prepositions and the principles of translating narratives and poetry and attempt a few exercises. In particular, we shall read the Masoretic text of the book of Jonah (a narrative with a poem) with the help of the Lexicons/Dictionaries and other Bible aids.
outcome: Knowledge Outcomes The students will be competent in the following abilities: (a) recognize every component in the parts of speech learned in THEO 3217 (b) identify the binyanim and functions of all verbs (c) recall the forms and functions of the prepositions and particles (d) identify, recognize at least 500 of the most common Biblical Hebrew words found in the Hebrew Bible (e) search words in the Biblical Hebrew dictionaries and lexicons and explain the entries, in particular the BDB Lexicon.  (f) parse and translate given phrases/sentences and the book of Jonah  (g) use the parsing tools of Bible Works 10  Attitude Outcomes The students will: (a) be confident to read a Biblical Hebrew passage on their own with the necessary tools (b) develop the habit of reading Biblical Hebrew passages  (c) appreciate the basic tasks to do exegesis and interpretation

title: History of Christianity in China
description: The development of Christian thought and institutions in China.
outcome: 1. Students shall obtain a general knowledge of the major historical developments of Christianity in China from the seventh century to present. 2. Students are expected to forge their own understanding and evaluation towards the key issues emerged when Christianity encountered the Chinese contexts. 3. Students shall get acquainted with different perspectives/models of Christianity in China, as well as with the issues which are still debatable nowadays. 4. Through both the lecture teachings and tutorial discussions, students shall develop a historical and theological sense towards the diversity of Christian expressions in China and are expected to critically reflect on the process of Christianity indigenisation/contextualisation in Chinese history.

title: History of Christianity in Hong Kong
description: This course aims at an in-depth study about the historical development of Christianity (including Protestant and Catholic churches) in Hong Kong since the beginning of the British rule. This study will emphasize the role of Christianity in the wider context of the history of Hong Kong, with special focus on the relationship between Christianity and Hong Kong society (education, medical care, social service, social action, etc.) and various issues arising from these areas.

description: An examination of some basic problems or topics related to history of Christianity.Offerings with different subtitles can be taken up for credit, up to a maximum of two times.

title: Theology and Feminism
description: This course will survey feminist theory, its use in feminist theologies, and implications of selected issues in feminist theory for theology in general.

title: Local Church Study
description: The main aim of this course is to help students to acquire a basic understanding of the local churches. The contents include brief introductions to historical, theological as well as sociological dimension of the local churches. Basic knowledge of congregational studies and methods of church analysis will also be introduced.

title: Homiletics
description: This course will cover: (1) the principles, construction and technique in preaching; and (2) the content and message of a sermon in the contemporary world. Student’s preaching will be videotaped and discussed for improvement of technique and content.
outcome: 1. To understand the principle of preaching on theological topics. 2. To understand the integration of different types of preaching and the way of preparation. 3. To learn and practice the techniques and styles in delivering a sermon.
syllabus: 一、 課程評估 分享／引論 聽道／講道經驗及心得 何謂講道學（Homiletics）？ 講道的構成因素——真道、表達、使命、講者、聽眾、技巧、權柄  二、 真道 何謂道？ 聖經與道 宣講與教導之不同 道與行  三、講章的分類 專題式講道 經文式講道 釋經講道  四、講章的性質 佈道 培靈 奮興 牧養 婚禮 喪追思 紀念日 聖曆及特別主日  五、經文的選擇與運用 用一段經文的好處 選擇經文要留意的地方 如何運用經文  六、如何決定主旨 主旨的必要 主旨的選擇  七、如何決定題目  八、講章的結構 分段與大綱 引論、本論、結論  九、導言 三個目的  十、例證 講道的天窗  十一、結論與應用 應用的重要性 應用的三個成份 應用的動機  十二、講章的準備和組成的步驟 探索期 專注期 講章的組合 最後的準備  十三、講道的技巧 講者的素質與風格 講章的表達與演繹  十四、學生試講

title: Denominational Tradition and Polity
description: This course is a study of the Protestant denominations that have made an impact in Hong Kong. The theological traditions, liturgies, polity, mission strategies and models of Anglican, Church of Christ in China, Methodist and Tsung Tsin Church will be studied.Offerings with different subtitles can be taken up for credit, up to a maximum of two times.

title: Sex, Marriage and Family
description: This course is designed to provide students with an opportunity to deepen their understanding of the issues and feelings surrounding sex, marriage and family. It is also designed to allow students to develop skill and sensitivity in ministering to individuals and families.

title: Liturgics
description: The history, theory and practice of public worship.
outcome: The course aims at equipping students with the understanding of the history and theology of the sacred worship, which include the development of the sacred worship, the notion of liturgical time, of ecclesiastical year, of sacred space, of Monastic and Cathedral office, of the liturgy of the hours. It also helps student to gain a critical understanding on various liturgical terms, liturgical vessels, books and vestments. Contextualization of liturgy in Chinese/Hong Kong contexts will also be discussed.
syllabus: Session 1 Corporate Worship and Church Life; Worship in Truth and Spirit; Worship as Dialogue.  Session 2 Design and Discharge in Worship. The Study of 1 Corinthians 14; The Planning of the Order of Service; Writing of corporate prayers and mediation for the lectionary.  Session 3 Worship as Offering; Old Testament Sacrifices, Levitical Priesthood and the Church as a Royal Priesthood.  Session 4 Time as Communication: The Christian Calendar; the Lectionary.  Session 5 Corporate Worship in Light of The Book of Revelation  Session 6 Space as Communication; Christian Art and Worship.  Session 7 Worship as Pastoral Care: The Funeral and the Wedding Service; Special Occasions.  Session 8 The Sacraments and Corporate Worship—The Rite of Initiation-Holy Baptism.  Session 9 The Sacraments and Corporate Worship—The Rite of Continuation— Eucharist  Session 10 Worship as a Drama—The Western Roman Catholic tradition; Vatican II Liturgical Reform; Worship as a Journey--The Orthodox Church tradition.  Session 11 The Protestant Tradition: The Normative and Regulative Principles of Liturgical Reforms: Reformed, Lutheran, Anglican.  Session 12 The Non-conformists: Quakers, Free Church, and Charismatic; The Seekers- friendly services.  Session 13 The Function of Congregational Singing in Corporate Worship; Hymnology

title: Preaching
requirements: Prerequisite: THEO3241.
description: Through instructions and discussion, students are given guidance in their composition and delivery of sermons. title: Death and Dying
description: This course is designed to provide students with an opportunity to deepen their understanding of the issues and feelings surrounding death and dying. It is also designed to allow students to develop skill and sensitivity in ministering to others.
outcome: A. Knowledge Outcomes 1. To enhance the ability of individuals to formulate, analyze, and deepen one’s own opinion on death-related practices and ethical issues. 2. To heighten sensitivity about cultural variations in dying, death and grief.  B. Skill Outcome 1. To have the ability integrating the dying with the living.  C. Attitude Outcome 1. To strengthen a spirituality of hope and courage to face personal aspect of death.

title: Ecumenics
description: The study of various types of theological thinking including Fundamentalism, Pentecostalism, Evangelicalism, Catholicism, Liberalizm, Orthodoxy, etc.; the history of the ecumenical movement and issues in ecumenical theological thinking.
outcome: The students will be able to utilize the analytical framework of denominational and post-denominational distinctions to critically review and understand the present-day ecclesial landscape. They will consolidate their systematic-theological knowledge through recognition of diverse spiritual actualizations and they will be able to apply the learnt analytical skills across the ecclesial expressions in the political and social and in the liturgical and spiritual expression of the church.
syllabus: This interdisciplinary course will consider the subject of "World Christianity" and its potential impact on churches and families of churches in different contexts. As a course in ecumenics, we will integrate a wide range of disciplines, including history, theology, social science and cultural studies. A major part of the course involves teaching interdisciplinarity as a method in addressing ideas and issues in theology and world Christianity. This is a relatively new approach in theological studies which may be applied to other courses in other disciplines.The course will address common issues and theological themes: mission and ecumenism; Christianity in a world of religions; Christology; secularization; the environment; economic justice, gender, always bearing in mind their implications for churches in particular places, especially Hong Kong, as well as their global dimension. The two are necessarily related.

title: Field Education I
description: Students will be arranged to join internship programmes offered by churches or church organizations. title: Faculty Student Seminar I
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course aims to develop practical research and academic writing skills of students. They are required to choose a subject for a paper, to create a logical structure, and to construct their own arguments academically. Their papers will be presented at the seminars. Chosen topics of the paper should be related to theological areas such as systematic theology, biblical studies, church history, practical theology, gender theology and so on. Nevertheless, students are encouraged to discuss current issues and subjects of other disciplines relating to the modern world from a theological perspective. Students’ performances will be primarily assessed by their written papers and presentations, but also by their participation in the discussion session. They will be evaluated on their ability to think theologically, that is, to reflect upon major theological and social issues, to define current issues in theological terms, and theological issues from the perspective of other disciplines.
outcome: This course will enhance students’ research skills, critical thinking and independent learning. The former will be achieved through the students’ own discovery of a subject that concerns academic interests and is feasible within the time and word limit, reviewing certain academic discussion of their chosen subjects, creating appropriate research methodologies, searching for and selecting materials, making sound judgements, engaging in meaningful dialogue with the newly-discovered information and former knowledge, and finally drawing up a sensible conclusion. This learning process is totally dependent on students’ own initiatives, creativity, sensitivity to theological and other issues, diligence, writing skills, as well as the awareness of self-limitations which can be reflected by their actively seeking advice from course instructors and through discussion with student peers. Students will be encouraged to move out of their own ‘comfort zones’ in order to critically evaluate new information and knowledge and apply this to the contemporary context.
syllabus: 1. academic writing style2. structure of academic papers3. developing a good research topic & title4. developing a thesis statement and defend it5. how to write an Introduction6. literature review and the ways to argue for a research gap/agenda7. arguing theologically and reasonably8. writing an abstract9. Chicago-style citation10. academic honesty

title: Theology and Contemporary Critical Theories
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: Graham Ward, Regius Professor of Divinity at the University of Oxford, once remarked, "theology’s business has always been the transgression of boundaries. It is a discourse which requires other discourses for its very possibility." In this light, theological study is inherently interdisciplinary. Also, theologians are increasingly getting involved in praxis, which calls for them to have the expertise to critically examine the social, cultural, and political dimensions of everyday life. This course addresses these two aspects of theological study and focuses on the various ways theology can engage with contemporary critical theories in order to theologically analyze a society along the three media of speech, money, and power, as described by Jürgen Habermas. The course selectively covers the following contemporary critical theories and topics: the Frankfurt School and Dialectical Thinking in the Marxist traditions; Michel Foucault's Theories of Power, Knowledge, Truth, Subjectivity, and Ethics; Postcolonialism and Decoloniality; Critical Theories of Everyday Resistance; Critical Historiography; Critical Theory; Feminism and Queer Theory. In addition to a survey of the various approaches to critical theories, selected prominent critical theorists from each approach will be discussed. The theological implications of these theories will be examined through the lens of selected social issues and phenomena. Students will be required to conduct a theologically critical analysis of selected issues in their home society by adopting one of the critical perspectives. This course weaves together analytical approaches from the two disciplines to provide a theologically critical understanding of contemporary social issues.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students will acquire the ability to: understand the fundamentals of the methodology of critical theory, its historical trajectory, its relevance in the present day, and its theological implications in the study of society. utilize critical theory's tools to theologize how dominant social forces are manifesting in the world today. critically consider the possibilities and constraints of social progress from a theological perspective in the present day. conduct mini studies on pressing social issues, utilizing theological and critical perspectives from across disciplines.Students will develop the following skills: critical theological reasoning, especially concerning contemporary social issues. interdisciplinary skills required to analyse the world using theologically relevant critical theories.
syllabus: 1. The Origin and Basic Philosophy of Critical Theories and Marxism1a. Class struggle, the critique of capitalism, and ideology in the Marxist traditions1b. The Frankfurt School and dialectical thinking—Horkheimer, Adorno, Marcuse, Benjamin, psychoanalysis, etc.1c. Habermas’ theory of communicative rationality1d. Theological implications of the Frankfurt School2.      Michel Foucault's Critical Theories2a.      Foucauldian power, knowledge, truth, and subjectivity2b.      Foucault’s archaeology, genealogy, and ethics2c.      Theological implications of Foucault’s critical theoriesThe topics below will be covered selectively in different years:3.      Postcolonialism and Decoloniality3a.      Postcolonialism as a deconstructive reading practice, and a resistant discourse3b.      Postcolonial and decolonial dialogues3c.      Critical theories from the Global South3d.      Edward W. Said, Gayatri C. Spivak, Homi K. Bhabha, Aníbal Quijano, Walter Mignolo3e.      Theological implications of postcolonialism and decoloniality; postcolonial theologies4.      Critical Theories of Everyday Resistance4a.      Difference modes of resistance, and the theory and practice of everyday resistance4b.      James C. Scott’s everyday forms of resistance4c.      Michel de Certeau’s practice of everyday life4d.      Asef Bayat’s politics of subaltern and “informal people”4e.      Theologizing as everyday resistance5.      Critical Historiography5a.      Paul Ricœur and narrative5b.      Hayden White’s metahistory5c.      New historicism5d.      Theology, historiography, and politics of historical writing6.      Critical Theory, Feminism, and Queer Theory6a.      The origin, historical development, and various schools of feminism6b.      Major concerns of different schools of feminism6c.      Nancy Fraser’s debate with Habermasians6d.      Queer and identity politics6e.      The origin and major concerns of queer theory6f.       Foucault’s theses about regimes of sexuality6g.      Derrida’s deconstructionism and the binary opposition of male/female, homosexuality/heterosexuality6h.      Judith Butler’s theses on gender as performativity6i.       Feminist theology and Queer theology

title: Theology and Empirical Research Methods
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: “Experience” and reflection on it have always been a concern for theologians, despite the diversity of theological traditions that prioritize various aspects of the formative factors for theology in different ways. In addition, contemporary theologians and church leaders share a growing concern for praxis that transforms the world and the church. All of this necessitates that theologians comprehend experience not only on a philosophical and conceptual level, but also as inherently concrete and social. Consequently, theologians are becoming increasingly interested in distinctive categories of empirical data pertinent to theology and in distinctive research methodologies pertinent to the analysis of these data. This is especially true of practical theologians and empirical theologians, though it is not exclusive to them. In this light, as stated by the editors of the Eerdmans series of Studies in Ecclesiology and Ethnography, if theology is to have impact on the church and world today, theologians must learn to utilize empirical research tools to provide more accurate, disciplined, and contextually-grounded research.This course thus exposes students to a variety of empirical research methods and data analytic tools that will help them understand, evaluate, and conduct empirical research relevant to theological studies. The primary emphasis will be on qualitative approaches, but students will also learn how to read quantitative research reports critically. It aims to provide students with a foundation for integrating theological inquiry and empirical research in a manner that not only maintains the integrity of both disciplines but also employs social scientific methods in a manner that is "theological all the way through," as Helen Cameron has stated. Students will be required to conduct a mini-study on selected issues in their home society/church by adopting one of the empirical research methods.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, student should be able to: explain the role and importance of empirical research in theology. exhibit a critical understanding of empirical research methods and their application to theological inquiry. explain why a particular empirical method is preferable for answering a particular theological research question. differentiate and explain various qualitative research methodologies. develop open-ended questions for an in-depth oral interview and focus group interview. conduct qualitative data analysis manually and with software like NVivo.  explain the relationship between measurement and concept. critically comprehend basic statistical language. explain which ethical considerations must be incorporated into empirical research. formulate a theological problem that is amenable to qualitative research and develop an appropriate research design. reflect theologically on empirical findings and incorporate empirical findings into normative discourse.
syllabus: 1.       Modes of interaction between theological inquiries and empirical research methods1A.      The history of the use of social scientific methods in theological research1B.      Examples of how empirical research can be used in theological inquiries—empirical theology and practical theology1C.      The principle of "theological all the way through"2.       Qualitative approaches to inquiry (e.g., narrative, phenomenology and its variants, grounded theory and constructivist grounded theory, ethnography, case study, action research, etc.) 3.       Methods in qualitative research3A.      How to ask well-constructed, focused questions3B.      The role of theoretical framework in different kinds of qualitative research3C.      Data collection3Ci.          Methods of sampling3Cii.       Qualitative interviewing: structured, semi-structured, unstructured interview; individual in-depth interview and focus group interview, etc.3Ciii.     Field observations, ethnography, digital ethnography, etc.3D.      Qualitative data analysis, interpretation, and presentation3Di.      Various types of coding, thematic analysis, theorization, and standard computer-assisted data analysis software such as NVivo3Dii.   Strategies of data interpretation; the issue of trustworthiness, validity, and generalization4. The fundamentals of various quantitative research facets: key-terms and design, research questions, hypothesis, operationalization of concepts, instruments, questionnaire design, population, sample, common types of data analysis (univariate, bivariate, and multivariate analysis), and standard data analysis software such as SPSS, etc. 5.  How to critically read quantitative research reports6.  The use of mixed methods7.  Research ethics8. Theological reflection on empirical findings

title: Ecumenics
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity, MA in Theological Studies and MA in Christian Studies
description: The course studies the present landscape of unity and differences among Christians, in particular cross-denominational movements like ecumenism, evangelicalism, and the Pentecostal-charismatic movement. The course analyzes these movements and related ones like independentism, fundamentalism, and others, and considers how these different movements interact with social contexts, in what sense these movements have an ecumenical dimension, and how far they can be understood as genuine forms of contextualized Christian faith.
outcome: The students will be able to utilize the analytical framework of denominational and post-denominational distinctions to critically review and understand the present-day ecclesial landscape. They will consolidate their systematic-theological knowledge through recognition of diverse spiritual actualizations and they will be able to apply the learnt analytical skills across the ecclesial expressions in the political and social and in the liturgical and spiritual expression of the church.

title: Issues Facing Churches Today
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
description: The goal of the course is to explore what kind of issues churches are facing in contemporary world, to reflect and to recommend how churches respond to these challenges. The goal is not about the concern of survival, but about the concern of mission, Missio Dei. Apart from a lot of issues surrounding us, different agendas of churches (or denominations) make the selection of the issues for discussion more difficult. Due to this, the design of the course adopts an interactive approach, that is to say, we come to discuss, decide and analyze the issues for study. We work in a group, not individual, although assessment is individually based. At the same time, methodologies of theological reflection are introduced.

title: Women in World Missions
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies or MA Theological Studies
description: In the context of Christianity as a worldwide movement, the majority of church members are women. Since the early 1800s, women have led in cross-cultural ministries of service, witness, evangelism, and philanthropic works. In order to understand these phenomena, this course will explore the context, nature, theory, and issues relating to women in world missions with particular focus on the 19th century to the present. In addition to examining important global issues for women in missions, it will cover women encounter with local culture through which to explore any selective appropriation of Western Christianity from intercultural perspective.

title: Christianity and Ecology
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course explores the ways in which Christianity is responding to environmental issues. Environmental crisis raises economic, social, biological, legal, moral and theological concerns. This course interprets Christian responses to environmental problems from an interdisciplinary perspective. This course will introduce students to the major theologies of ecology and strategies for action.

title: Selected Reading of the Hebrew Bible
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
description: This course selects one major script or some minor scripts of the Hebrew Bible for studies. Issues including textual criticism, authorship and readership, sources, themes and theology will be discussed. The interpretations of these issues by scholars will also be incorporated.

title: Selected Reading of the New Testament
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
description: This course selects one major script or some minor scripts of the New Testament for studies. Issues including textual criticism, authorship and readership, sources, themes and theology will be discussed. The interpretations of these issues by scholars will also be incorporated.

title: Development of Early Christian Communities
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
description: This course deals with the situation of Early Christian Communities mainly in the 1st century CE. The reconstruction of this situation is mainly based on the critical studies of the scripts of the New Testament. The social situation and religious thought in the time of Jesus Christ, St. Paul, and the texts of the canonical Gospels are the main foci of this course.

title: Extracanonical Literature
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity and MA in Theological Studies
description: This course deals with the ancient texts ranging from about 3rd BCE to about 3rd CE and including the Old Testament, Pseudepigraphies as well as the New Testament Apocrypha. Introductory issues, such as authorship, language and manuscripts are included. The theologies of the literature, which represented different stages of the development of different sects or schools and contributed to the development of Early Christianity, will be studied.

title: Hebrew Bible Exegesis
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies; Hebrew I (THEO1213 or THEO3217 or THEO5301) and Hebrew II (THEO1214 or THEO3218 or THEO5302)
description: This course continues from the basics of Biblical Hebrew I and II. It introduces the technical skills and steps involved in the exegesis of the Hebrew Bible. Therefore, the student will be taught the foundation of exegesis, how to use and read BHS (Biblia Hebraica Stuttgartensia) and BHQ (Biblia Hebraica Quinta), including textual criticism. The student will also learn to do lexical studies, analyze syntax with the appropriate tools. Students will learn to apply these skills on a few texts of different genres: poetry: Ps 23; instruction: Prov 2; and others. Through these primary skills, the student will be guided how to exegete the texts and also explore possibilities of interpretations.

title: New Testament Greek Exegesis
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies; New Testament Greek I (THEO1215 or THEO3215 or THEO5303) and New Testament Greek II (THEO1216 or THEO3216 or THEO5304)
description: This course aims at enabling students who have learned New Testament Greek I & II to do translation and thence exegesis of the Greek text independently.

title: Narrative Art in the Hebrew Bible
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity, MA in Christian Studies
description: Most parts of the Hebrew Bible is written in narrative form. In recent years, the literary approaches to the narrative in the Hebrew Bible are proliferating. The aim of this course is to explore the artistic and literary features of the narrative in Hebrew Bible. Students will learn how to appreciate the so-called poetics of the narrative in different parts of the Hebrew Bible, including the Pentateuch, the Former Prophets and the short stories of Jonah and Ruth, and acquire skills to analyze these narratives from a literary perspective. Furthermore, students will reflect on how the literary nature of the narrative in Hebrew Bible influences our view on Bible as History and Scripture.
outcome: After this course, students should be able to • recognize and describe different artistic features in the Biblical narrative  • appreciate the narrative art in the Hebrew Bible  • analyze the narrative in the Hebrew Bible from a literary perspective  • theorize the relationship between Biblical narrative, literature, history and theology  • reflect and design on the various use of Biblical narrative in different contexts

title: Deuteronomistic History
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course covers the major scholarship pertaining to the so-called Deuteronomistic History (DH), a perceived coherent literary unit that encompasses the books of Deuteronomy, Joshua, Judges, Samuel and Kings. It provides an overview of the major models on the literary production of the DH as put forth by the historical-critical scholars throughout the 19th to 21st century and examines the literary structure, central themes, and textual issues of these books by positing them within the literary culture of the ancient times. It traces the development of the current debates on the DH that both challenge various suppositions in the original formulation of the theory and yet continue to assert the validity of the overall thesis.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:• Describe and compare the original and various modified theories of the DH• Appreciate the contributions that the historical critics have made to elucidate the relations between Deuteronomy and the Former Prophets.• Deepen their awareness of the intellectual milieu in which this scholarly construct has originated and problematize the anachronistic elements of the original thesis • Demonstrate a familiarity of the current approaches to the reading of the DH

title: Christianity in Chinese Literature
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity and MA in Theological Studies
description: This course adopts an innovative approach to examine the interactions between Christianity and Chinese literature from the 19th to early 20th centuries. Literary texts to be analyzed include mainly the late Qing missionary novels, and works of May Fourth writers (such as Lu Xun, Bing Xin and Xu Dishan). This course aims to widen the students' perspectives in the indigenization of Christianity in Chinese religious and literary contexts, the rhetorical influences of the Bible on the emergence of modern Chinese literature, and the interdisciplinary study of literature and religion.

title: Protestantism in Reform China
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity, MA in Theological Studies, MA in Christian Studies, MA in Religious Studies
description: The aim of this course is to help students to understand the development of Protestant Christianity in the Reform era in China, with emphasis on the interactions between Christianity and political, social and intellectual changes in China. Topics include church-state relationships, the Three-self Patriotic Movement, denominational and theological reflections, etc.

title: Studies in Hong Kong Christianity
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity, MA Theological Studies or MA Christian Studies
description: This course examines the significant changes of Hong Kong society and its impacts on the development of Christianity since 1950s. Emphasis will be placed on social movement, political changes, 1997 issues, educational reform, as well as cultural and intellectual transformation. This course also explores the theological responses of Christian churches to the above challenges.

title: Christianity in the Chinese Diaspora
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
description: This course examines the development of Christianity in Chinese Diaspora. Emphasis would be laid on the cases in Hong Kong, Taiwan, Macao, Southeast Asia and North America. Students shall examine and reflect on the trends of globalization and localization by comparing the experiences in various contexts.

title: God,Creation,and Eschatology
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: Since God in Christian understanding is self-revealed, the knowledge of God is not just about a language game. Through and in Jesus Christ, we come to know God as Trinity and Creator in terms of alpha and omega. This course attempts to provide a biblical, historical, theological, philosophical and contextual analysis of the doctrine of God.
outcome: 1. To review critically the concepts of God, creation and eschatology from a historical-theological approach. 2. To correlate the doctrines of God, creation and eschatology to other Christian doctrines. 3. To apply the knowledge and skill developed in the course creatively to Christian liturgical and ethical life. 4. To make formal presentation on the theme of the doctrine of God, creation and eschatology to the Christian communities
syllabus: 1.Classical Theism2.Theology in Postmodernity3.God as Gift4.God as Becoming5.Radical Trinity6.Creation7.Nothingness8.Evil or Divine Providence9.Kairos and History10.Future or Present11.Messianism without Messiah

title: Christ,Church,and Spirit
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: Christ, Church and Spirit are intimately correlated in the Christian faith. This course attempts to provide a biblical, historical, theological, contextual and practical analysis of these three doctrines and their relation.

title: Theology and Feminism
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity, MA in Theological Studies, MA in Christian Studies, MA in Religious Studies
description: The absence of women’s experiences and voices often seems the result and perpetuation of a blindness to gender inequality within the Church. To change this reality, we must return to a basic question: What does Christian theology reveal to the Church about the nature and place of women? The course aims at exposing students to a broad perspective and discussion about the dynamic relationship between theology and feminism. In addition to introducing the experiences of contemporary women and feminist critiques on violence, family, sexuality, poverty, ecology and media, the students will be encouraged to reexamine the ways in which the Western Judeo-Christian religious tradition has profoundly influenced our understanding of God and gender and to study the feminist interpretations of God-talks, sin and redemption, spirituality, leadership and church.
outcome: 1. Delineate the historical oppression of the female gender in Church History and the Judeo-Christian traditions. 2. Review and describe the theological history of women’s identity, status and role in the family, church and society at large.  3. Analyze and criticize how theologies are formulated against the female gender in Christian history until today. Evaluate how formulations of the God-talk and other aspects of theology are also influenced by such theologies. Comment and specify the abuse, violence, subversion and impoverishment of the female gender and their relation to ecology.  4. Research and reconstruct female presence in history and Christian sources.  5. Describe and explain what constitutes gender, sexuality, and female embodiment, and draw implications on these discourses in the academia. 6. Construct practical frameworks to educate and raise awareness of the oppression, and also propose ideas how to promote a just and righteous community of faith and society.
syllabus: 1.Introduction: The Emergence of Christian Feminist Theology; FT as Intersectional Theology2.The Construction of the Other3.Workshop Brainstorming: Tell the OTHER Stories4.Art Workshop (Full Day): I and the Other in God, Facilitated by Liu Kwok Hong5.Feminist Theology as a History of Theology6.Asian Feminist Theology and Post-Colonial Christology7.Ecofeminist Theologies8.Open Ceremony of the Exhibition: The Other and Me in God9.Feminist Theology as Embodied Theology10.Disability Theologies11.Queer Theology12.Building up Ekklesia Community

title: Hermeneutics and Theology
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity, MA in Theological Studies, MA in Religious Studies
description: This course will examine the impact of contemporary hermeneutical theories on the doing of theology. A survey of the development from classical to modern and contemporary hermeneutics will be given. The influence of hermeneutical theories upon theological method, the rethinking of the nature of theology, the interpretation of bible, the explication of some theological categories, will be introduced.

title: Modernity and Theology
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
description: This course examines the relation and interaction between modernity and theology, with particular focus on the challenges of modernity to Christian theology as well as the diverse theological responses to modernity in various historical and cultural contexts. Related issues, such as the contested interpretations of modernity, claims about the theological roots of Western modernity, and the prospect of constructive theology in global modernity, will be discussed.

title: Theological Systems and Methods
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
description: This course examines and evaluates selected works of modern systematic theologians, such as Friedrich Schleiermacher, Karl Barth, Paul Tillich, Wolfhart Pannenberg, and Gordon Kaufman. It will investigate the structure and content of each theological system as well as the method used in constructing it. Special attention will be paid to the interdependence of method and system. While the course focuses on modern and contemporary theology, it will briefly survey a few classical examples of systematic theology, such as the works of John of Damascus, Thomas Aquinas, and John Calvin.

title: Political and Liberation Theologies
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
description: Both political and liberation theologies attempt to provide a theological reflection of the interaction between the Christian faith and the socio-political order, with reference to their particular context. They keep an active and critical dialogue with contemporary social theories. Issues like church-state relation, Christianity and human rights, Christianity and economic justice are their concern. The course not only introduces the historical development and the theological significance of political and liberation theologies, but also explores to construct a political and liberation theology that is relevant to the contemporary context.

title: Chinese Christian Thinkers
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
description: This course is an in-depth study of the theological perspectives of several Christian thinkers in modern and contemporary China. Case studies include T.C. Chao, Watchman Nee, Y.T Wu, Wang Mingdao, K. H. Ting, etc. Special reference shall be made on the distinctive characteristics of their theological concerns, as well as their impact on Chinese Protestantism. Their contributions on Christianity indigenization and contextualization shall also be discussed.

title: Cinema and Theology
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
description: This course considers the various religious and theological dimensions of contemporary cinema, and examines a range of approaches to such endeavours. Since the inception of motion picture in 1895, cinema and institutional religions (including Christianity) have always been interested in each other – numerous films have used religious themes and motifs as subject matters, while religious communities have been eager to harness the cinema by critiquing, censoring, or making use of films in their ministries. The study of film from serious academic theological perspectives, however, was scarce until the mid 1990s. In this course, we explore a number of approaches by which the theological study of film can take place. These include, for example, the study of explicit representation of religious materials, the 'uncovering' of implicit religious motifs, the use of film as resource for theological reflection and construction. In particular, we shall consider how cinematic representations of certain important theological motifs may enrich conventional religious understanding. Films to be viewed and discussed cover a broad range from European art-house classics, popular Hollywood productions, to contemporary East Asian and Chinese language films.

title: Congregational Studies
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
description: This course will familiarize students with the recent discourse of congregational studies flourished both in the US and the UK context. Students will be helped to see the significant impact that this discourse has on recent congregational life. Interdisciplinary research methods for understanding the identity, dynamics, and context of a congregation will be introduced. Students will also be equipped with some tools for analyzing the local congregations.

title: Christian Mission and Glocalization
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
description: God’s mission (Missio Dei) is the fundamental of mission, and should be understood in context. The history of the Christian mission reveals that its mission is like an ‘Empire’ as well as a servant of the gospel. Apart from a critical review of the theology and practice of Christian mission, the course is to analyze the characteristics of glocalization and its implications for the understanding and practice of Christian mission.

title: History, Practice, and Theology of Christian Worship
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity, MA in Theological Studies, MA in Christian Studies, MA in Religious Studies
description: The course is designed to provide students with an in depth study of Christian Worship from Biblical, historical, liturgical, theological and contextual perspectives. After laying the foundation for liturgical and theological discussions from Biblical and historical angles, much emphasis will be placed on the development of worship forms from Vatican II to the recent ecumenical and post denominational liturgical revivals that reflect dynamic contemporary cultural and theological dialogues in the post modern era.

title: Twenty-First Century Hymnology
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
description: This course aims at the study of hymns and the development of church music in historical perspectives. It will investigate how hymns, as carriers and interpreters of 2000 years of Christian faith, have laid their biblical foundation, and have incorporated historical and cultural elements as well as their respective musical styles to enrich the liturgy and shape our spirituality. It will also examine how the hymn explosion of the latter part of 20th century has opened up a new world of 21st century hymnology, which on the one hand has incorporated new vocabularies to deal with issues of human rights, social, economical and political justice, ecology and integrity of creation, and on the other hand has adapted musical languages of the modern world with diversified ethnic styles that has formed a new world of 21st century global hymns. Emphasis will be placed on the analysis and application of contemporary hymns and praise choruses musically, theologically and liturgically.

title: Models of Practical Theology
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
description: This course aims at familiarizing the students with the practical theology movement in the past several decades. It will examine the practical nature of all theologies, and will introduce several models of practical theology. It also aims at helping students to see how the theological theories that they learn through lectures and readings may have bearings on their Christian lives and ministries.
outcome: Knowledge: Students acquire the following and/or critically reflect on them-- 1. Reconceiving theology as a practical science; 2. History, traditions and schools of the practical theology movement going on since the 1970s; 3. Methods and Methodologies of doing practical theology; 4. Read at least one classic text in the field of practical theology.  Attitude: students be able to fully appreciate that theological study is practically-oriented; Skill: students be able to  1. critically do theory-practice integration via theological reflection; 2. critically transfer the knowledge learnt to at least two aspects of Christian practice.
syllabus: What is Practical Theology?-Nature of Theology—Theoretical or Practical or “theoretical vs. practical”? -Duns Scotus and the debate over the nature of Theology in the Thirteenth/Fourteenth Century -Practical Theology as a discipline—historical development -Types/ Models/ Paradigms of Practical Theology -On Practical Theology in Chinese Speaking Societies -Methods and methodologies of Practical Theology ---Empirical (qualitative inquiry) approach -----the approaches widespread in the British circles -----Illustrations --------A research on Protestant Death rites --------Spiritual Care in multifaith settings ---Practical Theology as Action Research ---Hermeneutical Approach -----theory and practice, application -----What is “Practical”/”Practice”? -----“Application” and Understanding: the Fundamental Hermeneutic Problem -----Illustration: Wesleyan reflection on Pathological Gambling ---Stephen Pattison’s Practical Theology as “Critical Conversation” ---Practical Theology as Critical Social Theory -----Illustrations: --------Lutheran reflection on local Higher Education in the context of Economic Globalization --------Church Growth discourse (HK) --------WHO spirituality vs. Asian Spirituality -----Class Experiment: enjo kosaiSome Domains (examples) of Practical Theology: -Theological Education -Theological Reflection ---Models of theological reflection ---Disjuncture and theological reflection ---Learning style and theological reflection -----Reflection via integrative seminarIntegrative Seminar x 4: -Students’ presentation (no audit [except special students] is allowed)-by random assignment: 8 presenters + 8 reflection partners (2, 2, 2, 2) -Each reflection partner group consists of two students who will engage in pre-session reflection with the two presenters separately.

title: Sex, Marriage and Family
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
description: This course aims at familiarizing the students with a practical theological approach to issues in connection with sex, marriage, and family. The contents cover the changing conceptions of sex, marriage, and families in the course of history, as well as the Christian traditions that give shape to the conceptions. Debates on the related issues and the theologies underneath will also be discussed. Besides, some related Christian counseling approaches will also be included in the course contents.

title: The Reformation Era
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: The 16th century brought a profound paradigm shift in the development of Christianity that has fundamentally changed church, society, and culture in the West. This change has had a global impact and played a crucial role in the process of modernization. The course introduces the students to the developments in church, theology, and society in 16th century Europe with a particular emphasis on the deep theological changes, particularly those connected to Luther, Calvin, and the Radical Reformation.
outcome: • Students shall be able to systematically and coherently understand different aspects of the transformations happening during this period: theological, spiritual, historical, social, political, and others.  • Students will extend their knowledge to how shifts in theological thinking affected the traditional configuration of society, state, culture, and religion • The students will develop skills to make appropriate judgments about different perspectives on church history and issues that are still debated. • The students will develop sensitivity regarding the diversity of Christian faith expressions. • The students will learn to apply theological concepts based on the theoretical paradigms of the Reformation to assess controversial issues of the present.
syllabus: • Political, social, and cultural context of the late medieval time • Medieval theology as background to the theological debates of the Reformation • Historical aspects of the main reformers Luther, Zwingli, and Calvin and of the Reformation in England • Systematic theological aspects of Reformation thought: o Soteriology   o Sacraments   o Ecclesiology   o Political theology • Historical aspects of the post-Reformation period • Reforms in Roman Catholicism • Ecclesial, cultural, social, and political impacts of the Reformation

title: Modern Western Christianity
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: The purpose of the course is to introduce the students to the historical and theological developments in the Western Church from the Peace of Westphalia through Enlightenment, the history of awakenings and the renewals in the 20th century to the present. This course includes both developments of the church in Europe and North America, as they are closely linked.

title: Biblical Hebrew I
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity and MA in Theological Studies
description: This course, and the sequel Biblical Hebrew II in the next semester, are designed to enable students to read Biblical Hebrew. In this course, Biblical Hebrew I, students learn the alphabets to the basic forms of Hebrew sentences. Students not only learn how to read simple sentences from the Hebrew bible, but also learn to identify different parts of speech, and basic grammar. Students will also learn some Hebrew songs which accompany the lessons. This course follows closely to its textbook, Learn Biblical Hebrew by John H. Dobson (2005). Biblical Hebrew I will cover Lessons 1-13.

description: This course, a sequel to Biblical Hebrew I, will continue to follow the textbook, Learn Biblical Hebrew by John H. Dobson (2005), covering Lessons 12–25. title: Introduction to the Hebrew Bible
requirements:
For students in Master of Divinity
Exclusion: THEO5919 The Hebrew Bible in Contexts
description: This course orientates students to the diverse scholarship which encompasses the study of the Hebrew Scripture: from archaeology, historical-critical, grammatico-historical, socio-historical methodologies to the history of composition of the biblical books, languages, religions and literature of the period before the common era. Inevitably, it also introduces the world of the ancient Near East – its history, religions and literature, which the Hebrew Scripture belonged and related to. This course traces the challenges confronted bythe nation of Israel from its beginning up until the period of the Second Temple.
outcome: Knowledge Outcomes: 1. The students will know and understand a. the general overview of the contents in the Hebrew Bible b. the direct relationship of the composition of the books to her contexts c. a general grasp of the scholarship pertaining to the study of the Hebrew Bible 2. The students can describe, explain and discuss a. the main issues related to the composition and redaction of the books in the Hebrew Bible b. the main issues of critical scholarship concerning the origin and identity of Israel c. the proposed historical contexts of the Hebrew Bible d. the relationships or/and tensions between the traditions underlying the theological motivations and the contemporary  e. situation/s of the text  Attitude Outcomes: The students will appreciate  a. the making/compilation of the Hebrew Bible b. the necessity for language acquisition in the study of the Hebrew Bible c. the diverse research faculties in the study of the Hebrew Bible

description: The main purpose of this course is to give students a general understanding the text of the New Testament, its methods of studies, its background and the issues involved. title: Wisdom and the Psalms
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course studies the “wisdom” genre of the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament, namely Job, Proverbs, Ecclesiastes, Ecclesiasticus and the Wisdom of Solomon, and some wisdom passages in the prophetic genre, as well as the book of Psalms. It studies the concept of “wisdom” in these books, and their distinction from, and relation to the other books of the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament. At the same time, it also considers its relationship to the ancient Near East genre of instruction literature.

title: Synoptic Gospels
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course comprises a study of the purpose and theology of the Synoptic Gospels (Matthew, Mark and Luke), comparing their distinct characteristics and looking at their similarities and differences. The course begins with a critical survey of the history of the Synoptic problem (how to explain the relationship between Matthew, Mark, and Luke) and proposed solutions. Exegesis of selected passages will be carried out to understand the original setting of individual gospel.

title: Johannine Literature
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course will include a study of the authorship, purpose and main themes of the Johannine literature. Special attention will be given to some selected passages from the Gospel according to John, the Epistles of John and Revelation (Apocalypse).

title: Pauline Letters
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course is a study of the Pauline and Deuteropauline Letters. Through comparing some of the critical passages from both categories, the course will explore the dating, authorship, purpose and the development of the Pauline theology.
outcome: Knowledge Outcomes: 1. To have basic knowledge of the content, theology and historical context of Pauline Letters; 2. To have basic knowledge of historical Paul; 3. To be able to understand particularly the first letter of Pauline Letters (i.e. the Letter to the Romans); and 4. To be able to grasp the method of Bible study and exegesis, particularly Pauline Letters.  Skills Outcomes: 1. To enhance critical intelligence thinking; and 2. To develop one’s ability to have a critical and yet sympathetic understanding and appreciation of different church traditions and scholarly perspectives; and 2. To develop one’s sensitivity to the limit of doctrines and enhance openness to different exegesis.

title: Pentateuchal Studies
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course covers the major scholarship pertaining to the books of Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers and Deuteronomy. It not only examines the themes and historical purposes for these books, but also orientates the students to the complexities of the contents and purposes for these books as evidenced by the prominent scholarship throughout the 19th to the 21st century. It tracks the recent development of the debates pertaining to the source theories of J, E, D and P; and also recent alternative theories and methodologies to the study of the Pentateuch.

title: Prophetic Literature
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course covers selected readings from the second portion of the Hebrew bible, the Prophets, in particular the latter prophets, which includes Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel and the book of the Twelve (Minor Prophets). Historical studies aided with contextual interpretations will be the approach taken in engaging the biblical text, while theological and exegetical studies of the text will interact vigorously with contemporary social, political, economic and cultural dimensions of the public life. Insights and influences from modern literary and critical theories, social sciences and humanities, and various inter-disciplinary approaches will also be introduced and applied in the course of interpretation.

title: The book of Ezra-Nehemiah and the books of Chronicles
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course focuses on the books of Ezra, Nehemiah and Chronicles in the Hebrew Bible, which are important parts of Hebrew Bible Historiography reflecting the situation of the Jews in the Second Temple Period. The scholarship associated with the Second Temple/Persian Period is also soaring in new and exciting frontier which we hope this course can help students to follow such a trend. Issues including textual criticism, authorship and readership, sources, theme and theology will be discussed.

title: Early and Medieval Church
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: The purpose of the course is to introduce the students to the historical and theological developments in the early and medieval church, from Jesus to the dawn of the Reformation and to engage them in a critical dialogue with earlier forms of contextualization of the Christian faith.
outcome: a) The students will gain a general knowledge of the theological and ecclesial development during the covered period.  b) The students become familiar with key doctrinal development and the interplay between religious institutions and socio-political circumstances of the early and medieval period of the church. c) The students will get acquainted with different perspectives on church history and with issues that are still debated. d) The students will develop sensitivity regarding the diversity of Christian faith expressions and gain historical depth in their theological reflection. e) The students learn about historical forms of contextualization. f) The critical study of church history helps the students to recover the voices of those who have been condemned as heresy.

title: History of Christianity in Hong Kong
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course aims at helping students to gain a comprehensive understanding on the history of Protestant Christianity in Hong Kong. The first section will emphasize on the historical development of Christianity in different stages. The second section will investigate the relationship and interaction between Christianity and Hong Kong society from topical perspectives.

title: History of Christianity in China
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course aims at giving the students a macro historical picture of Christianity in China from the seventh century to the present. Special attention will be paid to the interaction between Christianity and the Chinese society.
outcome: Learning outcomes (1) To assist students to understand the historical development of Christianity in China (2) To assist students to acquaint the methods of conducting research on Chinese church history Attitude Outcomes (1) To develop and affirm students’ identity towards Chinese church history
